author: Amber Thomas

intro.value: If you’re looking to add a new furry friend to your family, you may be encouraged to “adopt not shop”.
But where do adoptable dogs in <select class=stateSelect>Washington</select> come from?
This question can be complicated, but let’s start with a dog named Bleu.

dogDescOut.value: Bleu was one of 1,265 dogs available for adoption in Washington on PetFinder, June 28, 2019. But Bleu didn’t originate in Washington. According to his description, he was brought into the state from a shelter in California.
On the day that Bleu was available, 27% of the adoptable dogs in Washington came into the local rescues and shelters from out of state.

dogDescOut2.value: So, if these dogs weren’t strays or surrendered by their owners locally, where did they come from?

dogDescIn.value: Bleu was one of 1,265 dogs available for adoption in Washington on PetFinder, June 28, 2019. And, like all the other adoptable dogs in the state, Bleu originated in Washington.
But Washington is one of only 13 states that didn’t import adoptable dogs from other states or countries. In fact, Washington exported 55 adoptable pups to other states.

exportedTitle: Where imported dogs in Washington come from
exportedSub: Based on PetFinder data for adoptable dogs on June 28, 2019

movementTitle: Imports and Exports of Dogs by State
movementSub: Based on PetFinder data for adoptable dogs on June 28, 2019

preMovement.value: Shelters and rescue organizations have been moving animals around the country, reportedly, since the mid 2000’s, with some pointing to Hurricane Katrina as the primary catalyst. Evacuation plans during the detrimental 2005 storm didn’t account for moving or accommodating pets or stray animals so an estimated 250,000 animals were left behind.

Louisiana’s SPCA and other rescue organizations from across the country worked to save an estimated 15,000 animals during the aftermath of the storm. Then these animals were transported all across the country to wait to be reunited with their families or to eventually find a new one.

Since then, new legislation has been enacted to ensure that pets are a planned part of evacuations and rescues still work during emergencies to provide safety for animals. But these days, the transport of animals goes far behind emergency response.

In 2018, the ASPCA reports that they relocated over 40,000 animals from areas of “high homeless pet overpopulation” to “areas with a higher demand for adoptable dogs”. Although our data is a snapshot of animal movement, representing all the adoptable animals available across the country on a single day, we can see geographically where animals are exported from and imported to.

movementNote: Note: All dogs displayed as exported from a particular state are also depicted as imported to another state. In this graphic, there are more imports displayed than exports since some imported dogs came from outside the US. Each import into the state was determined by parsing the PetFinder description for each animal. More details in the Methods section.
